reviewText: I felt that Jacqueline Bisset, as Anna Karenina, and Christopher Reeve, as Count Vronsky, were miscast. To me they did not appear to be passionate lovers willing to give up everything for each other. Anna Karenina is a very powerful story however this version seemed to lack the necessary intensity to make it believable. There seemed to be no real attraction on the screen between Anna and Count Vronsky. They gave the impression of reading a script. I thought the best performance in the movie was given by Paul Scofield as Karenin, Anna's husband. The 1948 version starring Vivien Leigh as Anna Karenina seemed much more convincing. I think the best version I have seen is the 1934 Anna Karenina starring Greta Garbo and Frederick March. Of course it is all a matter of personal taste which performance is more enjoyable and which actor and actress are more believable.
summary: Not one of the best versions

reviewText: Note: I saw this movie on television a few hours ago.Having seen several film versions of Leo Tolstoy's classic (and mammoth) novel ere I saw this, I knew the story well enough (and I'd only recently read the book for the first and last time 9 months ago). I was unaware of this version until i came across it by chance on Amazon. Unfortunately, it's not on DVD, so imagine my complete surprise to find it airing on OVATION a few days ago. I looked when it was going to be aired again, and I decided to watch it today.This made-for-television production of Leo Tolstoy's epic novel is worth viewing for the performances by Ms. Bisset and Superman. Mr. Reeve does a very good English accent, though why neither he, Ms. Bisset or Mr. Scofield (an academy Award winner for A Man For All Seasons) didn't try a Russian accent is something I don't know. The screenplay, however, is a colossal mess. Constantine Dmitrich Levin, a crucial character in the novel, is omitted entirely and only mentioned twice or thrice. The heartwrenching scene of Anna seeing her son for the last time (and on his birthday, no less!) is rearranged, so that it is merely another day in his life, and not his birthday. Other scenes from the book get the same shoddy film treatment here.See this film once, and then view the 1927, 1935, 1948 and or 1997 versions. They're closer to the original novel.Not Rated.
summary: Superman Proves Once Again That He Is Human. Good Acting, Sloppy Script.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This beautiful classic love story with its beautiful classic stars has been slashed almost beyond recognition.  What is even more upsetting is this version of this movie in its original presentation was at least 2 hrs 18 mins. long.  I know this to be true because I saw it on TV and taped it at that time. (Since giving this review, I have learned that even the version I taped had been cut.  I understand this movie originally ran about 2hrs & 40 mins.)  I have been hunting for this movie as it was originally meant to be seen for years.  I bet there are many, many people who would have been happy to pay additional cost to get "the whole thing".  I rated it 5 stars because the costuming & locations are so beautiful and the chemistry between Christopher Reeve and Jacqueline Bisset is a sight to behold.  But whoever made the decision to produce this short version should be ashamed.  My big hope now is that it will be rerun and I will be fortunate enough to catch it and tape it again.
summary: THE BEST ANNA KARENINA THAT IS AVAILABLE -  BUT
Title: N/A

reviewText: HEAVILY EDITED VERSION WAS LIKEY ONCE GREAT BEFORE BEING SHORTENED, NOW DATED AND MIDDLING1985 TV Movie with Jacqueline Bisset and Christopher ReeveIf any version desperately needs a restoration, this is the one.  I think this was probably pretty impressive though the acting style leans more towards the 70's melodramatic.  Production values get an update with more atmosphere appropriate to 80's style.  Sadly, existing copies in any form I know of are not complete due to editing or shortening.  Sound and visual quality are very poor, nearly bad VHS level.  However, the acting (in the context and style I mentioned) are more evenly delivered from all the actors compared to some renditions where some performances are weak.  The flow is still less choppy than some productions despite the shorter run time.  In the context of the shortened version, this one doesn't really fail in any given area, but also does not distinguish itself beyond other versions.  Until a restoration, I am afraid this one is a little non-descript.BRIEF COMPARISONS TO OTHER EDITIONS with links to the product  (this list is not comprehensive and I apologize if a favored version is not represented.  I already watched nearly 24 hrs of video not counting research and writing!)  This list is not in order of precedence and each version has merits.  You can see slightly more detailed versions of my reviews like the paragraph above by going to each product page.1977 BBC Mini SeriesAnna Kareninawith Nicola PagettThe Gold Standard of adaptations even after so many years.  Despite the 70's BBC acting style, this version has aged well with tremendous faithfulness to the book and ideas behind it.  Performances are melodramatic to today's audience, but so good they are relevant.  It is still my favorite rendition.  You must be up for nearly 10 hrs worth of story though.2000 Materpiece TheaterMasterpiece Classic: Anna Karenina, Part 1with Helen McCrory and Kevin McKiddThis version is the next longest I viewed and fairly faithful to the plot and spirit of the book.  The acting style is more natural (less stage play melodramatic) and the entire focus seems to be on a realistic portrayal.  Lead actors less compelling than I would have liked.  This version will still be some peoples' favorite.  It is not mine.1948Anna Kareninawith Vivien Leigh and Kieron MooreClassic black and white is a different style and shouldn't be compared too critically with modern adaptations.  It has the charm of a golden age of cinema.  Leigh is perhaps still the most elegant Anna and Kieron Moore the most dashing Vronsky after all this time.1997 Bernard Rose versionLeo Tolstoy's Anna Kareninawith Sophie Marceau and Sean BeanMost visually stunning of the traditional adaptations, gorgeous cinematography and recognizable stars galore.  Despite all the stars, acting is uneven and accents all over the place.  Choppy story flow.  Still one of my favorites!2012 Art film by Joe WrightAnna Kareninawith Kiera KnightlyThis is not for Tolstoy traditionalists!  However, the stunning visuals and choreographed set pieces really are brilliant.  It is set like a stage play and tends to swirl around a lot.  I hated it the first time because I wanted something else.  Understanding it better, I like it more.
summary: TRESPASS AND FORGIVENESS -- COMPARISON OF 6 VERSIONS OF KARENINA --- with links

reviewText: Well financed production values and lavish, authentic interiors provide the cold framework for this film that can't decide what aspects of the story to stress, so developments seem singular to this particular case and no generalizations are suggested or offered. This betrays Tolstoy's sharply defined vision of a morally bankrupt, glittering Russian society that winks at suavely conducted adulteries, but crushes women who make the error of being sincere. Moral hypocrisy and a cold, logical consistency are the attitudes mobilized by Russian society to stigmatize such women, and Tolstoy shows them motivating Anna's husband who uses them like chess pieces. Unfortunately, the film shrinks the husband's role in the story and the film meanders from event to event, as if no event is more important than any other, and ends by presenting us with an unhinged Anna, without offering any indication of what went wrong. A deeper and more satisfying account of the Karenina tragedy is offered by the two earlier b&w films starring Greta Garbo and Vivian Leigh respectively. I gladly rest content with them; the path of remakes is strewn with blind alleys and casual approximations.
summary: Events are reduced to the stature we meet with in everyday life today.  An inert Scofield lets everybody down.
